text: X One morning , about ten days after Mrs. Churchill 's decease , Emma was called downstairs to Mr. Weston , who " could not stay five minutes , and wanted particularly to speak with her . "-- He met her at the parlour - door , and hardly asking her how she did , in the natural key of his voice , sunk it immediately , to say , unheard by her father , " Can you come to Randalls at any time this morning?--Do , if it be possible . Mrs. Weston wants to see you .

"

text: He stopped at Highbury , at the Bates 's , I fancy , some time -- and then came on hither ; but was in such a hurry to get back to his uncle , to whom he is just now more necessary than ever , that , as I tell you , he could stay with us but a quarter of an hour.-- He was very much agitated -- very much , indeed -- to a degree that made him appear quite a different creature from any thing I had ever seen him before.--In addition to all the rest , there had been the shock of finding her so very unwell , which he had had no previous suspicion of-- and there was every appearance of his having been feeling a great deal . "

text: But I shall always think it a very abominable sort of proceeding .
text_tokenized: But I shall always think it a very abominable sort of proceeding .

text: What has it been but a system of hypocrisy and deceit,--espionage , and treachery?-- To come among us with professions of openness and simplicity ; and such a league in secret to judge us all!--Here have we been , the whole winter and spring , completely duped , fancying ourselves all on an equal footing of truth and honour , with two people in the midst of us who may have been carrying round , comparing and sitting in judgment on sentiments and words that were never meant for both to hear.--They must take the consequence , if they have heard each other spoken of in a way not perfectly agreeable !
text_tokenized: What has it been but a system of hypocrisy and deceit,--espionage , and treachery?-- To come among us with professions of openness and simplicity ; and such a league in secret to judge us all!--Here have we been , the whole winter and spring , completely duped , fancying ourselves all on an equal footing of truth and honour , with two people in the midst of us who may have been carrying round , comparing and sitting in judgment on sentiments and words that were never meant for both to hear.--They must take the consequence , if they have heard each other spoken of in a way not perfectly agreeable !

text: " " I am quite easy on that head , " replied Mrs. Weston .
text_tokenized: " " I am quite easy on that head , " replied Mrs. Weston .

text: " I am very sure that I never said any thing of either to the other , which both might not have heard . "
text_tokenized: " I am very sure that I never said any thing of either to the other , which both might not have heard . "

text: " You are in luck.--Your only blunder was confined to my ear , when you imagined a certain friend of ours in love with the lady . "
text_tokenized: " You are in luck.--Your only blunder was confined to my ear , when you imagined a certain friend of ours in love with the lady . "

text: " True .
text_tokenized: " True .

text: But as I have always had a thoroughly good opinion of Miss Fairfax , I never could , under any blunder , have spoken ill of her ; and as to speaking ill of him , there I must have been safe .
text_tokenized: But as I have always had a thoroughly good opinion of Miss Fairfax , I never could , under any blunder , have spoken ill of her ; and as to speaking ill of him , there I must have been safe .

text: At this moment Mr. Weston appeared at a little distance from the window , evidently on the watch .
text_tokenized: At this moment Mr. Weston appeared at a little distance from the window , evidently on the watch .

text: His wife gave him a look which invited him in ; and , while he was coming round , added , " Now , dearest Emma , let me intreat you to say and look every thing that may set his heart at ease , and incline him to be satisfied with the match . Let us make the best of it -- and , indeed , almost every thing may

Let us make the best of it -- and , indeed , almost every thing may

text: be fairly said in her favour .
text_tokenized: be fairly said in her favour .

text: It is not a connexion to gratify ; but if Mr. Churchill does not feel that , why should we ?
text_tokenized: It is not a connexion to gratify ; but if Mr. Churchill does not feel that , why should we ?

text: and it may be a very fortunate circumstance for him , for Frank , I mean , that he should have attached himself to a girl of such steadiness of character and good judgment as I have always given her credit for-- and still am disposed to give her credit for , in spite of this one great deviation from the strict rule of right . And how much may be said in her situation for even that error ! "
text_tokenized: and it may be a very fortunate circumstance for him , for Frank , I mean , that he should have attached himself to a girl of such steadiness of character and good judgment as I have always given her credit for-- and still am disposed to give her credit for , in spite of this one great deviation from the strict rule of right . And how much may be said in her situation for even that error ! "

text: " Much , indeed ! " cried Emma feelingly .
text_tokenized: " Much , indeed ! " cried Emma feelingly .

text: " If a woman can ever be excused for thinking only of herself , it is in a situation like Jane Fairfax's.--Of such , one may almost say , that ` the world is not their 's , nor the world 's law . '
text_tokenized: " If a woman can ever be excused for thinking only of herself , it is in a situation like Jane Fairfax's.--Of such , one may almost say , that ` the world is not their 's , nor the world 's law . '

text: " She met Mr. Weston on his entrance , with a smiling countenance , exclaiming , " A very pretty trick you have been playing me , upon my word !
text_tokenized: " She met Mr. Weston on his entrance , with a smiling countenance , exclaiming , " A very pretty trick you have been playing me , upon my word !

text: This was a device , I suppose , to sport with my curiosity , and exercise my talent of guessing .
text_tokenized: This was a device , I suppose , to sport with my curiosity , and exercise my talent of guessing .

text: But you really frightened me .
text_tokenized: But you really frightened me .

text: I thought you had lost half your property , at least .
text_tokenized: I thought you had lost half your property , at least .

text: And here , instead of its being a matter of condolence , it turns out to be one of congratulation.--I congratulate you , Mr. Weston , with all my heart , on the prospect of having one of the most lovely and accomplished young women in England for your daughter . "
text_tokenized: And here , instead of its being a matter of condolence , it turns out to be one of congratulation.--I congratulate you , Mr. Weston , with all my heart , on the prospect of having one of the most lovely and accomplished young women in England for your daughter . "

text: A glance or two between him and his wife , convinced him that all was as right as this speech proclaimed ; and its happy effect on his spirits was immediate .
text_tokenized: A glance or two between him and his wife , convinced him that all was as right as this speech proclaimed ; and its happy effect on his spirits was immediate .

text: His air and voice recovered their usual briskness : he shook her heartily and gratefully by the hand , and entered on the subject in a manner to prove , that he now only wanted time and persuasion to think the engagement no very bad thing . His companions suggested only what could palliate imprudence , or smooth objections ; and by the time they had talked it all over together , and he had talked it all over again with Emma , in their walk back to Hartfield , he was become perfectly reconciled , and not far from thinking it the very best thing that Frank could possibly have done .
text_tokenized: His air and voice recovered their usual briskness : he shook her heartily and gratefully by the hand , and entered on the subject in a manner to prove , that he now only wanted time and persuasion to think the engagement no very bad thing .
